> how to make PLOP to run grub ? In this case by running a DOS on the floppy and running from it grub.exe. But if PLoP on that BIOS does NOT see (2) it is vain. From your previous post I had gathered that PLoP "saw" (2) but couldn't boot from it. @sambul16 Each USB stick has a controller. Different makes/types of controlllers may have different capabilities. 99.99 % of sticks are sold set as single LUN (one device). Most controllers can be set as two LUN's (two devices). These two devices can be (it depends on the contoller): * hd (protected)+hd * fd+hd * cd+hd
To change the controller settings so-called "Mass Production Tools" or "Manufacturer's Utilities" are used. These are usually COMPLETELY or nearly completely UNDOCUMENTED apps that operate at a very low level on the device. They are very usefule as they usually, apart the above settings can set/reset: * the "removable/fixed bit" * the wear leveling/bad sectors mapping * device serial * device ID * device VID * device PID * etc. Besides formatting or reformatting the device at a low level that may be able to recover functionalitues of a "dead" stick. Obviously they are also VERY risky ![:frusty:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/frusty.gif) due to their undocumented status coupled with their great "power". See here for an example of how a tool like the one describes looks: [http://www.msfn.org/...howtopic=137990](http://www.msfn.org/board/index.php?showtopic=137990 "External link")
![:worship:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/worship.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.author: sambul61
forumNotes.content:
**mateuszek**   

- does Win Explorer see 2 separate drives or partitions when you connect the Thumb?  
- what does Win Disk Management Console show when you insert the Thumb?  

Can you show screenshots of the above?  

OR, the FDD is in fact written to MBR of the Thumb HD drive? If not, what is written to MBR of the Thumb - Plop, which you now try to replace with Grub4DOS MBR? In that case, what was originally written to the Thumb's MBR after you formatted it with the above tool and installed OS?  

--------------------------------------  

As to booting the Thumb HD after booting to its FDD (more accurately just launching Plop that way but not booting OS on the FDD), the Plop developer when [***asked***](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=12781 "External link") abundantly [***stressed***](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=12781&view=findpost&p=111949 "External link") that when you use Plop HD Menu, Plop can ONLY boot the USB HD device selected as first boot device in BIOS, or you **must reconfigure** the Thumb HDD boot files properly, setting the Thumb's drive letter according to its current order in BIOS drive list. Editing boot.ini is not required, when booting same Thumb from Plop USB Menu.  

Also he [***said***](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=12781&view=findpost&p=111852 "External link"), when you use **Plop HD Menu** items, BIOS routing is used to boot the item you selected (and it may fail to boot the USB HD Thumb). When you use **Plop USB Menu** item, Plop own routing and driver is used to boot the same item you selected (and it may also fail for a different reason, but offers yet another boot method). Which item from what Plop Menu did you use?  

Wonko suggested you to try chainloading Grub4DOS from Plop, or possibly installing Grub4DOS MBR to the Thumb FDD instead of Plop MBR. Have you done that? Try using *find --set root* method to avoid setting fixed Thumb HD volume number.  

Try answering separately each question stated in this post (i.e. with a question mark "?"). Each post on this forum is not only a direct help to someone, but also educational experience for other forum participants. Your complete answers are valuable input for others. ![:frusty:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/frusty.gif)

> i dont know what is on mbr of floppy after i formatted it, modded, probably nothing or some useless shit just like on new floppy from store.... ![:worship:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/worship.gif)
A floppy has ***NO*** MBR. (as it is NOT partitioned)  
It's first sector is the bootsector or PBR/VBR.  
The general idea of a ***Master*** Boot Record is to choose among various available Boot Records (i.e. various partitions, each starting with a Partition Boot Record or bootsector).  

![:worship:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/worship.gif)

forumNotes.author: sambul61
forumNotes.content:
Plop developer said that when you use Plop USB Menu (instead of Plop HD Menu), it uses its own detection instead of BIOS detection. But Plop driver is not universal enough to boot any Thumb with any chipset, especially the latest ones. Also it attempts to recognize the Thumb's chipset limited number of times. That's why my Sandisk Blade at times booted with Plop and at times didn't.  

There is another option to boot a Floppy diskette first, and then boot your USB Thumb from that diskette. But I don't think, you're up-to it. Not clear so far, **what Plop Menu** you were using when booting the 2-nd drive: HD or USB?  

Yet another important factor, I mentioned in the above linked [***Tutorial***](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=13171 "External link"), is about Thumb geometry and *jaclaz* 's paper on that topic - its right at the top of the Tutorial. So it may be wise for you to try this: wipe your Thumb, and then follow that paper to set correct Thumb geometry. Award 2009 BIOS may boot your Thumb after that. I guess, you used SMI Chip Utility to format the Thumb - now try other tools from that paper. It can make the difference you look for, and for starters you might not even need to divide the Thumb into 2 drives. ![:worship:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/worship.gif)  

The last thing to remember, there may be NO universal solution currently available, given key BIOS role in boot process, and great number of BIOS versions on the market. Not everything depends on the end user, no matter how hard you try. Not to discourage you, but a reality bit. ![:worship:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/worship.gif)
